On the simplest scale invariant Tree-Tensor-States
preserving the quantum symmetries of the antiferromagnetic XXZ chain

CÃ©cile Monthus Institut de Physique ThÃ©orique, UniversitÃ© Paris Saclay, CNRS, CEA, 91191 Gif-sur-Yvette, France
Abstract

For the line of critical antiferromagnetic XXZ chains with coupling J>0ğ½0J>0 and anisotropy 0<Î”â‰¤10Î”10<\Delta\leq 1, we describe how the block-spin renormalization procedure preserving the Sâ€‹Uqâ€‹(2)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘2SU_{q}(2) symmetry introduced by Martin-Delgado and Sierra [Phys. Rev. Lett. 76, 1146 (1996)] can be reformulated as the translation-invariant scale-invariant Tree-Tensor-State of the smallest dimension that is compatible with the quantum symmetries of the model. The properties of this Tree-Tensor-State are studied in detail via the ground-state energy, the magnetizations and the staggered magnetizations, as well as the Shannon-Renyi entropies characterizing the multifractality of the components of the wave function.

I Introduction

Quantum information ideas [1] have profoundly changed the perspective on many condensed matter problems (see the book [2] and references therein). In particular, various real-space renormalization procedures have been reinterpreted from the point of view of Tensor Network States (see the reviews [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9] and references therein) with the following output for the ground state of one-dimensional quantum spin chains : the Density-Matrix-RG introduced by S. White [10] corresponds to Matrix-Products-States that are well adapted to describe non-critical states displaying area-law entanglement, while the traditional block-spin renormalization for critical points corresponds to scale-invariant Tree-Tensor-States. In addition, this way of thinking has produced completely new types of renormalization procedures, like the multi-scale-entanglement-renormalization-ansatz (MERA) [11, 12] for critical models, where â€™disentanglersâ€™ between blocks are introduced besides the block-coarse-graining operators already present in Tree-Tensor-States (more details can be found in the reviews [5, 6, 7, 8]).

As stressed in the review [13], the â€™oldâ€™ block-spin renormalization procedures and the â€™newâ€™ tensor-network approaches have remained different in their aims : the goal of block-spin renormalization is to produce some explicit tractable RG flow for the few parameters of the initial Hamiltonian, while the Tensor Network activity is more oriented towards the production of very powerful numerical algorithms, based on the variational optimization of the whole Tensor Network representing the ground state wave function, and where the numerical precision can be systematically improved by increasing the dimension of the elementary tensors. Nevertheless, it seems useful to establish some bridges between the two points of view, at least on specific examples. In the present paper, we thus consider the critical line of the XXZ antiferromagnetic chain, for which Martin-Delgado and Sierra have proposed a simple block-spin procedure that takes into account the Sâ€‹Uqâ€‹(2)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘2SU_{q}(2) symmetry via the introduction of boundary fields in the intra-block Hamiltonian [14, 15, 16]. Here, we describe how the obtained solution can be reformulated as the simplest scale-invariant Tree-Tensor-State compatible with the quantum symmetries of the model, and analyze in detail its various properties.

The paper is organized as follows. Section II contains a reminder on the XXZ chain and the quantum group Sâ€‹Uqâ€‹(2)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘2SU_{q}(2). In section III, we discuss the construction of scale-invariant Tree-Tensor-State compatible with the quantum symmetries of the model. In section IV, the scaling properties of local operators involving one spin or two spins are analyzed, in order to compute the ground-state energy, the magnetizations and the staggered magnetizations. The section V is then devoted to the Shannon-Renyi entropies that characterize the multifractality of the components of the wave function. Our conclusions are summarized in section VI.

III Scale-invariant Tree-Tensor-State preserving the Sâ€‹Uqâ€‹(2)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘2SU_{q}(2) symmetry

III.1 Coarse-graining with blocks of b=3ğ‘3b=3 spins

III.3 Choice of the isometry wğ‘¤w preserving the Sâ€‹Uqâ€‹(2)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘2SU_{q}(2) symmetry

The choice of the isometry wğ‘¤w is the point where the traditional block-spin renormalization approach and the Tensor-Network perspective differ.

In the traditional block-spin renormalization approach, the isometry wğ‘¤w of Eq. 28 is chosen by requiring that the two kept states |ÏˆjÂ±>ketsuperscriptsubscriptğœ“ğ‘—plus-or-minus|\psi_{j}^{\pm}> are the ground-states of some â€™intra-block Hamiltonianâ€™ involving only the three initial spins (Ïƒ3â€‹jâˆ’2,Ïƒ3â€‹jâˆ’1,Ïƒ3â€‹j)subscriptğœ3ğ‘—2subscriptğœ3ğ‘—1subscriptğœ3ğ‘—(\sigma_{3j-2},\sigma_{3j-1},\sigma_{3j}). The â€™computational advantageâ€™ is that the diagonalization of the three spins Hamiltonian usually gives simple explicit results for |ÏˆjÂ±>ketsuperscriptsubscriptğœ“ğ‘—plus-or-minus|\psi_{j}^{\pm}> as a function of the couplings of the Hamiltonian. The first â€™theoretical drawbackâ€™ is that there is some arbitrariness in the decomposition of the Hamiltonian into â€™intra-blockâ€™ and â€™extra-blockâ€™ contributions that can lead to completely different outputs, so that the quality of the results will strongly depend on the â€™clevernessâ€™ of the choice of the intra-block Hamiltonian. The second â€™theoretical drawbackâ€™ is that the choice of the ground states of the â€™intra-block Hamiltonianâ€™ does not take at all into account the â€™environmentâ€™ of the neighboring blocks.

In the Tree-Tensor-Network perspective (see the reviews [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9] and references therein), one represents instead the whole ground-state wavefunction |ÏˆNGâ€‹S>ketsubscriptsuperscriptğœ“ğºğ‘†ğ‘|\psi^{GS}_{N}> as a tree-tensor-state involving isometries, and the choice of the isometries is based on the minimization of the total energy

ENGâ€‹S=<ÏˆNGâ€‹S|H|ÏˆNGâ€‹S>subscriptsuperscriptğ¸ğºğ‘†ğ‘quantum-operator-productsubscriptsuperscriptğœ“ğºğ‘†ğ‘ğ»subscriptsuperscriptğœ“ğºğ‘†ğ‘\displaystyle E^{GS}_{N}=<\psi^{GS}_{N}|H|\psi^{GS}_{N}> (37)

The â€™computational drawbackâ€™ is that this global minimization can usually only be done numerically. However, the number of parameters can be drastically reduced if one takes into account all the symmetries of the model (see the review [9] and references therein). In the following, we describe how the symmetries of the XXZ chain allows to constraint sufficiently the possible isometries of the smallest dimension in order to obtain an analytical solution.

(i) Translation-invariance : for models that are translation-invariant in the bulk, the isometries wjsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘—w_{j} of Eq. 28 are chosen to be the same in each block j=1,..,N3j=1,..,\frac{N}{3}. It is important to stress however that the decomposition into blocks breaks nevertheless the equivalence between the three spins inside each block : this issue will be further discussed below.

(ii) Scale-invariance : for translation-invariant critical models, the coarse-graining procedure can be iterated with the same isometry wğ‘¤w for the (lnâ¡Nlnâ¡3)ğ‘3(\frac{\ln N}{\ln 3}) layers representing the successive renormalization steps : the initial layer t=0ğ‘¡0t=0 contains the Nğ‘N initial spins Ïƒisubscriptğœğ‘–\sigma_{i}, the first layer t=1ğ‘¡1t=1 contains N3ğ‘3\frac{N}{3} renormalized spins Ï„jsubscriptğœğ‘—\tau_{j}, the layer t=2ğ‘¡2t=2 contains N9ğ‘9\frac{N}{9} second renormalized spinsâ€¦ up to the top layer t=lnâ¡Nlnâ¡3ğ‘¡ğ‘3t=\frac{\ln N}{\ln 3} containing a single t-renormalized spin representing the two degenerate ground-states of the whole chain. In summary at this stage, the ground-state wavefunction |ÏˆNGâ€‹S>ketsubscriptsuperscriptğœ“ğºğ‘†ğ‘|\psi^{GS}_{N}> is written as a translation-invariant scale-invariant tree-tensor state involving the same isometry wğ‘¤w everywhere in all layers.

(iii) Sâ€‹Uqâ€‹(2)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘2SU_{q}(2) symmetry : the presence of symmetries in tensor networks states is discussed in detail in the series of papers [21, 22, 23, 24, 25], and the present Sâ€‹Uqâ€‹(2)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘2SU_{q}(2) symmetry can be considered as a deformation of the Sâ€‹Uâ€‹(2)ğ‘†ğ‘ˆ2SU(2) symmetry analyzed in [23]. However, since we focus here only on tree-tensor state involving the isometry wğ‘¤w with the smallest possible dimension (Eq. 28), we do not need the full formalism described in [23] for general tensors in the presence of the SU(2) symmetry, but we can use the language of the initial spins Ïƒğœ\sigma and the renormalized spins Ï„ğœ\tau to simplify the analysis. The idea is to introduce the Sâ€‹Uqâ€‹(2)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘2SU_{q}(2) generators for the renormalized spins Ï„ğœ\tau similar to Eq. 12

Tzsuperscriptğ‘‡ğ‘§\displaystyle T^{z} =âˆ‘j=1N3Ï„jzabsentsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘3superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘—ğ‘§\displaystyle=\sum_{j=1}^{\frac{N}{3}}\tau_{j}^{z}

Since the Sâ€‹Uqâ€‹(2)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘2SU_{q}(2) representations for b=3ğ‘3b=3 spins (section II.5) contains a quadruplet j=3/2ğ‘—32j=3/2 and two doublets j=1/2ğ‘—12j=1/2 that have different quantum number r=Â±1ğ‘Ÿplus-or-minus1r=\pm 1 for the relabeling symmetry, one concludes that there are only two possible isometries that are compatible with the Sâ€‹Uqâ€‹(2)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘2SU_{q}(2) and the relabeling symmetry :

(a) the isometry wasubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘w_{a} based on the choice |ÏˆÂ±>=|aÂ±>ketsuperscriptğœ“plus-or-minusketsuperscriptğ‘plus-or-minus|\psi^{\pm}>=|a^{\pm}> of Eq 26

Physically, one expects that this coarse-graining based on Sâ€‹Uqâ€‹(2)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘2SU_{q}(2) representations with j=1/2ğ‘—12j=1/2 up to the whole ground state has a meaning only in the antiferromagnetic critical region

while the ferromagnetic critical region âˆ’1<Î”<01Î”0-1<\Delta<0 would require to consider higher representations and thus isometries of higher dimensions.

IV Magnetic and energetic properties of the tree-tensor-state

In this section, we describe the magnetic and energetic properties of the tree-tensor-state based on the isometry wasubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘w_{a} of Eq. 42, while the comparison with the isometry wbsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘w_{b} of Eq. 43 is postponed to section IV.5.

IV.3 Renormalization rule for the Hamiltonian

We have already seen that the contributions of the two links inside each block jğ‘—j are renormalized according to (Eq 52 )

V Shannon-RÃ©nyi entropies of the tree-tensor state

The groundstate wavefunction of manybody quantum systems have been found to be generically multifractal, with many studies concerning the Shannon-RÃ©nyi entropies in pure quantum spin models [28, 29, 30, 31, 33, 32, 34, 35, 36, 37, 38, 39, 40, 41], or focusing on the weight of the dominant configuration, for instance the NÃ©el state for the present XXZ model [26, 27, 42]. It is thus interesting in this section to analyze the multifractal properties of the tree-tensor-state.

V.2 Renormalization rule for the Renyi entropies

Let us thus describe the generalized dimensions of Eq. 86 for special values of pğ‘p starting from infinity.

For the isotropic case Î”=1Î”1\Delta=1 and the anisotropic case Î”=1/2Î”12\Delta=1/2, Eq. 96 corresponds to the values

and explain the simple relation found in Eq. 97 for the Tree-Tensor-State.

VI Conclusions

For the line of critical antiferromagnetic XXZ chains with coupling J>0ğ½0J>0 and anisotropy 0<Î”â‰¤10Î”10<\Delta\leq 1, we have obtained that the translation-invariant scale-invariant Tree-Tensor-State of the smallest dimension compatible with the quantum symmetries of the model corresponds to the block-spin renormalization procedure introduced previously by Martin-Delgado and Sierra via the introduction of boundary fields in the intra-block Hamiltonian to make it Sâ€‹Uqâ€‹(2)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘2SU_{q}(2) invariant [14, 15, 16]. Even if the final output is the same, we have explained the differences in reasoning between the two points of view : in the block-spin renormalization approach, the solution is based on the lowest eigenstate EaGâ€‹Sâ€‹(N=3)subscriptsuperscriptğ¸ğºğ‘†ğ‘3ğ‘E^{GS(N=3)}_{a} for the block of N=3ğ‘3N=3 spins (Eq. 74), while in the Tree-Tensor approach, the chosen solution is based on the best ground-state-energy per site e0subscriptğ‘’0e_{0} in the thermodynamic limit Nâ†’+âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to+\infty, after the resummation of the contributions of all the renormalization scales (Eqs 70 and 71). As a consequence, the two criteria could turn out to be different in other models. In the future, it would be thus interesting to see for other critical quantum spin chains whether the Tree-Tensor approach agrees also with some previous choices of block-spin renormalization or produces new solutions.

In the second part of the paper, we have described the energetic and magnetic properties of the Tree-Tensor-State, as well as the as the multifractality of the components of the wave function. Despite its simplicity, the Tree-Tensor-State turns out to be able to reproduce some exact results for the anisotropic case Î”=1/2Î”12\Delta=1/2, like the ground-state energy (Eq. 73) or the multifractal dimension Dp=1/2subscriptğ·ğ‘12D_{p=1/2} of Eq. 99. Further work is needed to understand whether â€™disentanglersâ€™ between blocks preserving the Sâ€‹Uqâ€‹(2)ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘2SU_{q}(2) symmetry can be introduced besides the block-coarse-graining in order to produce some simple analytical MERA for the XXZ chain.
